reviewText: Move over, Almodovar--but not just yet, since I have not found another movie by director Eusebio Pastrana, after this astonishing debut.  What he does is amazing, dispensing with a linear, organized plot and creating a surreal world of people crossing each other's paths and affecting them in unexpected ways.  Yet, that world is also very real.  A movie that requires the discipline of a "willing suspension of disbelief".  In other words, do not fight it or try to impose an order; let the sequence of images and plot lines flow, and go with them.  I rented it yesterday, immediately wrote a poem on it and then I bought it.  It pays to know something about the circle, the spiral and Sufi practice. of whirling.  Remember: "love is full of edges. Its cuts keep us alive"
Title: N/A

reviewText: Spinnin' is one of the strangest movies I have ever seen. I got frustrated almost immediately trying to follow what was going on - so frustrated that I almost turned it off; and if Alejandro Tous (who plays Gárate, one of the two leads) were not so beautiful and compelling I probably would have. But I finally gave up trying to make any sense of the movie and just let it carry me along on its strange and fitful way, and then I began to love it.I still don't have any idea how to describe this movie, except maybe to say that its driving theme is that every human being is different and wonderful. That's a pretty good message, and, in the end, it gets that message across more effectively than any other movie I can think of.The central story of a gay couple wanting to have a baby is just the framework around and through which a kaleidoscope of humanity weaves and spins in endless, vibrant, pulsing diversity. The final scene, with hundreds of people spinning like dervishes in the streets of Madrid, is in some ways one of the corniest scenes I have ever seen, but by the time it ended I was awash in tears of joy. It refused to let me stay detached; it FORCED me to get involved, to surrender to its insistent, relentless determination to move me.Other reviewers have criticized the jerky editing and the disconnect between the soundtrack and the action, as if people are dancing to different music from what we are hearing. I am convinced ALL of that is intentional.This is not a normal movie. This movie is like a kid who has discovered something wonderful and will do ANYTHING to get our attention so it can show us what it found. This is a movie determined above all else to shake its viewers OUT of the complacency most movies depend on to tell their stories. It grabs us by the shoulders and shakes us awake, so it can show us what a wonderful world we live in, and how wonderful every single one of us is.
summary: Very strange; but, in the end, very effective
Title: N/A

reviewText: What is it with our Spanish film making friends?  Their gay themed films are either filled with despair and tragedy or in the case of "Spinnin" have all these bizarre components that make you go "huh?"  I don't get it.  It felt like the writer was trying too hard to be "artistic" with the film.  What was with the "100 kisses"?  Or having characters only the audience can see?  It works great in Shakespeare, but felt like a distraction from the story in Spinnin.  Was the writer just out of film school and wanted to show that he learned all these story telling techniques?  The only saving graces of this film were:  the sexy main characters often seen lying naked in bed, and the message that gay parents are just as good as straight parents.  I'm giving the film an "ok" rating.  If you're kinda bored and want to see an artsy Spanish gay themed film, then go for it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Here is the summary of the film as listed on IMDB:_________________________________________________________________________"Spinnin' is a wonderfully exuberant, multi-layered Spanish drama. MADRID 1995. Garate and Omar are young, gay and in love, and want to have a child. After failed attempts with their female pals, they befriend Raquel, a pregnant woman whose partner has died of aids. Sound conventional? Spinnin' is anything but. It is a wildly entertaining, inventive and cheeky film that throws the audience in the centre of these friends' chaotic lives, and celebrates being alive."Garate and Omar are surrounded by myriad colourful characters: from new-born babies to Garate's 60 plus father who is falling in love again; to two policemen who list things that are important to them, in the desire that their lists match up; to a couple who are either kissing each other, or fighting - both with equal passion; and many, many others. There's not a dull minute in this whirlwind of a film. Surrender to the charms of Spinnin' and you will leave the cinema wanting to embrace each other, dance and throw your arms up in joy. A Festival highlight."_________________________________________________________________________Hmmmm, I'm not quite sure what to say about this one. It definitely falls into the "arty" category of film-making, with some unusual edits, symbolic sequences, etc. Now, I can appreciate this sort of film, but perhaps only to a limited extent. I found myself getting rather annoyed at the artistic self-indulgence of the film-makers many times throughout the film. Other negatives: there was one plot point that made no sense to me at all---where was the motivation?---and quite frankly, by the end I still hadn't figured out exactly who everyone was, and exactly what the relationships were between many of the characters.On the plus side, it did have a decent and interesting storyline and starred some very good actors. I would have loved to see this picture shot in a more straightforward, sensible manner. If it had been, I think I would have really liked it. But as it stands---eh. Your enjoyment of the film really will depend on how much you enjoy unconventional foreign films. For me---nope, not quite my thing, despite those aspects of the production that I really appreciated. So, a mixed review from me---I can't really say "yes" or "no" on this one, all I'll say is that your mileage may vary...(On a totally shallow note, I have to say---I thought a couple of the actors in this picture were gorgeous. Exactly the type that I find very appealing---heh.)

reviewText: This is a great little Spanish film of the `art house' variety. It is a multi layered `tapestry of love stories'. Set in Madrid of 1995 and has at it's heart the lives and loves of Garate (Alejandro Tous) and Omar (Olav Fernandez). They are gay partners who sort of want to have a child with a pair of lesbian friends, who want to share the child, but no one is convinced it will work.That is the basic plot and then there are loads of stories that are unrelated, except that they are about love. We have an Indian male and female, who live out their passions and fights on or near a park bench. They are never seen speaking. There is a news vendor whose wife is pregnant and has told him she also has a lover, the child could be either of theirs. My two favourites are a couple of gay cops, who keep trying to find if they are compatible by comparing lists of random subjects.There is also familial misunderstandings and a custody suit. Plus some apparently mad woman who just wants someone to be her `de fact partner' - she asks anyone and everyone.Couple all the above with random extras, including a guy who for no reason pirouettes onto the screen (in a tutu), and pirouettes off - for no apparent reason, a dancing fat bloke and people who seem to be keeping a running tally of how many kisses certain characters have had. These at first act like alienation devices, but after a while they become part of the fabric of the film.I know it all sounds disjointed and a bit mixed up, but it sort of works, there are a lot of issues dealt with including HIV, loss, bereavement and heaps and heaps of love. That is what saves this film, it has an almost childish attitude to affection, and the warmth that comes across pulls it all together. I felt it could have benefitted from some editing, but this is an unusual film, and it was probably the directors intention to include so many disparate scenes, as this is a tapestry and should be appreciated for that.If you think `avant garde' is French for `crap', then you will not enjoy, if you like European cinema and things a bit left of field, this will put a smile on your face.
summary: Life, death and love in a sunny 1995 Madrid
